We examine the effect of a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u)(k, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-ikx}u(x,t)dx \\) applied to the velocity field.

If an additional damping term, introduced at a later time \\( t_1 \\), affects the solution, will the Fourier transform of the solution at \\( t = T \\) still correspond to the evolution described by the initial PDE without the damping term?
Explanation: The introduction of a damping term (e.g., \\( -\\gamma u \\), where \\( \\gamma \\) is a damping coefficient) modifies the dynamics of the fluid flow. As a result, the Fourier transform of the final state will incorporate effects of this damping, deviating from the original undamped evolved state.
